content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash of code, not too simple.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This seems very fun and a good addition to codingame clash of code

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: To long for a clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Multiple solutions exist, so it is fun to think about it. The problem is easier that the statement explains it.

The provided task description appears to be clear and well-structured. However, one potential aspect that might be considered a "loophole" or an area for clarification is the exact definition of the input format. The task mentions reading an integer N followed by pairs of "folder-subfolder" or "grandparent-grandchild" relationships, but it doesn't specify how these relationships should be represented in the input.

For example, it's not explicitly stated whether each pair should be on a separate line, separated by spaces, or if there should be any delimiters or separators between pairs.

Adding a clear description of the expected input format would make the task even more precise and prevent potential confusion for those attempting to solve it.
Good fun, although I was hoping that when I dropped Test 4 into a geoplotter that it would trace out some amusing dot-to-dot picture.

Input section
* Next n lines: Please format "parent" and "child" as [[variables]].

Goal section
* It seems more common to draw a graph where the root node is at the top (rather than on the left) and the "childless" node is at the bottom (rather than on the right)?
(It's fine not to change those words.)

Thanks.

Credits for Test case 5 and Validator 5 respectively go to reddit users bookwench and Koeru. Links below:
https://www.reddit.com/r/AskReddit/comments/2nqgkv/what_is_the_longest_sentence_you_can_come_up_with/
https://www.reddit.com/r/WritingPrompts/comments/6pvln0/cw_without_repeating_a_single_exact_word_write/

Implemented the first one.
For the Goal section, yes the answer is to draw from root node (at top) to the last leaf node (at bottom).
It's just as input that the links come in one space-separated line per pair, so there the parent always appears on the left and the child on the right. I think it's unclear because I have that sentence before explaining what the input looks like. Thanks for flagging. I'll rework it.

Ok, that took a while, but I've changed Test 4 to now have a hidden message (not a picture, 24 points was too few for anything complex and this wasn't easy, haha).
Make sure to either convert to float format or find a geoplotter that supports "#.##[NS]#.##[EW]" format. :)

Thanks for the feedback, I've edited to emphasise more that the pairs are pairs of 'space-separated strings', and clarify in the constraints that neither string can contain spaces but can contain other ASCII characters. Let me know if you'd like any other adjustments.
Thanks, I've simplified the statement a bit now to make it clearer.
Thanks for the feedback, I've removed two of the examples from the statement because they made it look a lot longer than it is. Now it's just one example and much shorter, and hopefully clearer.

Oh, now I understand what you were trying to say. There should be a better way to explain that. Talking about the occurrences/locations of the words in the input exceeds the necessary explanation because it's explaining how to find the solution.

Yes, I've rephrased now as "[...] leads from a node that only appears as a 'parent' (the root node - the first folder/parent) to a final node that only appears as a 'child' (the last sub-folder)."

Talking of left/right was too hand-hold~y. Thanks for the feedback, as always.

Thanks. I would suggest to delete "(Note we start at "Animals" because it only appears on the left, and end at "Hellgrammites" as it only appears on the right = go from 'parentless parent' to 'childless child')" as well.
